FacilityName: Mid Missouri Agri Service - Sweet Springs

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

Facility:    Mid Missouri Agri Services
Location:    125 Lexington, Sweet Springs, Mo.
Contact:     Dan Tate
Phone:     660-335-6355

1. The Facility Policy

MFA Incorporated and the employees of the Mid Missouri Agri Services in Sweet Springs are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Sweet Springs Fire Department, and other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. Facility Information

The primary activity at the facility is the receiving, storage and distribution of anhydrous ammonia for direct application as a crop nutrient. The facility also handles grain. 

The facility has (1) 30,000 gallon storage tank, which is the largest tank onsite containing approximately 140,000 pounds. The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of a transport delivery truck holding approximately 50,000 pounds. The facility also has (24) 1,000 gallon nurse tanks, (2) 300 gallon applicator tanks for product distribution.

3. The Accidental Release Prevention Program.

The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1, 1981", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., the Missouri Anhydrous Ammonia Law and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".

4. The Five-year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that: have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



5. The Emergency Response Program.

The facility has;

    a. a written emergency acti

on plan, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;

    b. provided State and Local authorities with the emergency planning and community 
                right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

    c. a written emergency response program, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 
                1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training.

6. Planned changes to improve safety.

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. The facility has been evaluated to meet the requirements of ANSI K61.1-1999 and improvements will be made in the near future.
